text: This play was set in 1889 pre-flood. That was conveyed through some dowdy dresses
column4: costume top hats
column5: maybe a line about "the dam" and "rain"

text: And: The play's tension is to come from the idea that all of the characters in the play will be killed in the Johnstown Flood.
One of the older guys in the play at one point asked the writer/director why the play had no conflict. The answer? "It's a slice of life."
Another scene was the entire cast in baseball uniforms dancing around the stage. That was the "dream ballet" sequence
One scene(my big debut) was just people on stage pretending to prune flowers to decorate
column4: and to hang flag bunting for a Memorial Day Parade

text: One scene had her trying on her wedding dress. One scene had him talking to a man reading a newspaper about what it's like to be married.
The play was about a woman (Daisy?) and her fiancé and her best friend. They were preparing for her wedding. All very happy.
And the plot of what he had on paper curiously had no conflict. None
column4: zilch.

text: He handed us photocopied pages of the script
column4: and the last few scenes were missing. He was still "working on them"

text: On 1st day of rehearsal
column4: we showed up at the Arts Center thinking we'd head to a real theater. The director led us to a back storage room.

text: Little did I know that some of the juniors/seniors in my high school and even real adult pro actors gave up their summers to take roles too.
I got cast as Flower Girl 1. Or something like that. OF COURSE I was all in.
Our hometown would rebuild the shuttered steel mills and welcome theater festivals years in the future
column4: because of this play we originated

text: ...that we'd win AWARDS
column4: have HUGE audiences
column5: take it on the road and GET PAID $100-$1000 stipends
column6: depending on the role we landed

text: The director told us he was founding a significant cultural experience for all of Johnstown
column4: that the play would be BIG

text: My mom drove me to the church where they held the audition and sat in a pew while I read some scene about people buying...flags and flowers.
Of course 14-year-old me saw this as THE shot at stardom. So I auditioned for this director/playwright when the Arts Center put out the call

column4: was that Big City.

text: The play was called "Flags And Flowers." It was about the great Johnstown Flood of 1889
